review.title: Logic and Constraint Logic Programming for Distributed Constraint Optimization
review.abstract: The field of Distributed Constraint Optimization Problems (DCOPs) has gained momentum, thanks to its suitability in capturing complex problems (e.g., multi-agent coordination and resource allocation problems) that are naturally distributed and cannot be realistically addressed in a centralized manner. The state-of-the-art in solving DCOPs relies on the use of ad-hoc infrastructures and ad-hoc constraint solving procedures. This paper investigates an infrastructure for solving DCOPs that is completely built on logic programming technologies. In particular, the paper explores the use of a general constraint solver (a constraint logic programming system in this context) to handle the agent-level constraint solving. The preliminary experiments show that logic programming provides benefits over a state-of-the-art DCOP system, in terms of performance and scalability, opening the doors to the use of more advanced technology (e.g., search strategies, complex constraints) for solving DCOPs.

sections.heading: 3.5 Some Theoretical Considerations
sections.text: The solidity and completeness of the LP-DPOP system is a natural consequence of the solidity and completeness of the DPOP algorithm, together with the solidity and completeness of the CLP (FD) solver of SICStus Prolog. Since LP-DPOP emulates the calculation and communication operations of the DPOP, each of these programs is a correct and complete implementation of the corresponding agent. In the worst case, each agent in LP-DPOP, such as DPOP, must calculate, store and send a utility for each value combination of variables in the separator set of the agent. Therefore, both LP-DPOP and DPOP suffer from exponential memory requirements, i.e. the memory requirement per agent is O (maxDomw), where axDom = argmaxi | Di | and w is the induced width of the pseudo-tree.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusion and Future Work
sections.text: The use of a generic CLP solver to implement the individual agents proved to be a profitable option, far surpassing the existing DCOP technology in terms of speed and scalability. The paper also represents the tentative case for a different encoding of existing technologies; the ability to explicitly model hard constraints provides agents with additional knowledge that can be used to narrow the search space and further increase performance. In many ways, this is a preliminary effort that will be expanded in several directions. First, we believe that different types of DCOP problems can benefit from different types of local solvers within each agent; we are currently exploring the use of ASP as an alternative for coding the agents. The preliminary results are competitive and superior to those produced by DPOP. Classifying DCOP problems in a way that allows automated selection of what type of LP-based solutions to use.
